messages.content: LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Lessons from talking to 15 data science freelancers

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

After talking to 15 data science freelancers, this was one of my biggest takeaways 👇 

Learn the full tech stack. 

When doing data science work as a freelancer, one is often working alone 👨🏻‍💻 

This means that generating real-world value from a data science project is going to require you to go outside the typical data science skillset. 

Toward that end, my goal this quarter is to sit down with 4 data engineers and 4 ML engineers to get guidance on how I can learn the full DS tech stack. 

👉 If you (or anyone you know) are a DE/MLE and are willing to chat, shoot me a DM or drop a comment :) 

#datascience #dataengineering #MLengineering

--
Media: None

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Data science seems to be dying and ML/AI engineering is on the rise. Poll audience.

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

While Data Scientist may have been the “sexiest job in America” a few years ago, these days, it feels like that is changing. 

With new roles like data engineer, ML engineer, and (now) AI engineer, these specializations seem to be in greater demand than traditional data scientists. 

What's your sense? 

Is Data Science Dying?

--
Media: Poll
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Why machine learning is different than traditional software development and sharing YouTube video

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Although we can draw many parallels between traditional software (SW) developments and machine learning (ML), there are 3 critical differences. 

1) Computers are programmed by data, not humans ❌ 

2) ML systems are less predictable and less interpretable ◼️ 

3) Development is nonlinear 📈 

👉 In my latest YouTube video, I discuss these points in greater detail and do a hands-on walkthrough of a project I’ve been working on to implement semantic search over my YouTube videos. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇

--
Media: Video link
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
The value of RAG and sharing blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

One of the most in-demand AI projects these days is building a RAG system 🔥 

RAG (i.e., retrieval-augmented generation) improves an LLM by automatically providing it with relevant context to a user query or request. 

👉 In my latest Medium article, I give a beginner-friendly introduction to RAG and use it to improve a YouTube comment responder I created in a past post. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 😁 

❤️ A big thank you to Towards Data Science for publishing this article and all the others in my LLM series

--
Media: Blog link
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Communication challenges for data scientist. Promote blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

This is why data scientists don’t get promoted (hint: It’s not SWE) 👇 

A universal challenge for data scientists is communicating effectively with non-technical stakeholders. 

This was one of the biggest limiting factors for those seeking advancement when I worked at a larger enterprise. 

Here are 3 Communication tips that helped me get ahead as a data scientist. 

1) Use Stories—framing communication as 3-part narrative helps it go down easier e.g. status quo, problem, solution. 

2) Use Examples—examples make abstract ideas concrete. For instance, a 3-part narrative was used in this post. 

3) Use analogies—analogies help us learn new things by mapping the unfamiliar to the familiar, which is very handy when explaining technical ideas. 

👉 I share 4 more tips in the blog in a recent article published in Towards Data Science 

Check it out and let me know how you’ve improved your communication skills.

--
Media: Blog link
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
10 AI buzzwords explained

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

AI seems to be riddled with buzzwords these days. 

Here are 10 common AI terms every practitioner should know... 

1) RAG = automatically providing relevant context (i.e. docs) to an AI system so it can generate better responses
2) Vector DB = numerical representations of documents which can be used for RAG and search 
3) Fine-tuning = adapting a model to a particular use case through additional training 
4) AI Agent = an AI system that can plan and execute tasks 
5) Evals = tests that score an AI system’s efficacy 
6) Hallucination = a "made-up" response from an AI that sounds reasonable 
7) Multimodal = data of different formats (e.g. text, images, audio, videos, tables, time series) 
8) Small Language Models = LLMs with ~1B parameters 
9) Quantization = reducing the precision of model parameters to reduce its size 
10) Distillation = using a large model to train a smaller one 

—

 What's missing from this list?

--
Media: Notes screenshot
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
9 ways I made money in my first year of entrepreneurship and sharing custom AI workshops

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

In my 1st year as a full-time entrepreneur, I’ve made money in many different ways. 

Here’s a list (in descending order)👇 

1. Medium Blog 
2. AI Consulting 
3. YouTube 
4. Consulting Calls 
5. AI Workshop 
6. Referral 
7. Buy Me a Coffee 
8. Book Review 
9. Brand Collab 

While having many revenue sources sounds nice on paper, when you are a solopreneur, it can easily lead to spreading yourself too thin. 

That’s why I’m doubling down on one of these revenue sources: AI Workshops I like this offer because it aligns with my content creation efforts and allows me to stay connected with businesses using AI in practice. 

If you know anyone looking for custom AI workshops, referrals are greatly appreciated (Happy to give a 10% referral bonus 😁) 

👉 Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gHdZJY8P

--

LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
How to build client relationships as a data scientist

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

To be an effective data scientist focus on relationships, not technologies. 

While data science requires a minimum amount of technical proficiency, this isn’t the usual bottleneck for a data team’s impact 💥 

The more I’ve worked with clients on business use cases, the more I’ve realized how a shallow relationship and lack of trust can hinder a data project’s impact. 

Here are 3 things I do to cultivate a new client relationship 👇 

1) Be curious (about the problem and where the other side is coming from) 

2) Be transparent (about the limits of my skills and knowledge) 

3) Be myself (don’t try to put up a front—it’s unsustainable) 

Anything I can add here? 🤔

--
Media: Meme
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Lesson from posting 1 Youtube video a week

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Last quarter, I did an experiment where I posted 1 YouTube video every week. 

... it did not go as expected 😬 

My Hypothesis—Since YouTube drives 80% of my inbound traffic (e.g., paid calls, speaking gigs, project opportunities), doubling my video output will double my business. 

The Results—Almost every business metric went down e.g. number of paid calls, number of leads, subscribers per month, YT revenue per month 😅 

So what happened? 

My (current) guesses: 

- No LLM videos (these are among my most popular) 
- Less time per video diminished quality 
- I spent too much time making content and not enough time talking to clients and other folks working in the space (i.e. I got out of touch) 

That’s why this quarter, I’ll be scaling back my content quantity and focusing more on quality by… 

- Lowering my monthly YT video goal to 3 per month 
- Lowering my consultation rates (so I can stay connected with people’s needs) 
- Doing more project work as an intellectual break from making videos

--
Media: Image
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Multimodal RAG and its value. Share blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Two major topics in AI this year were multimodal models and RAG. 

But… what if we brought these ideas together? Multimodal RAG systems are capable of processing text and non-text data. 

This enables more powerful solutions beyond what is conveyed by text alone. 

For example, it could analyze someone’s facial expressions and speech tonality to give a richer context to a meeting’s transcription. 

In my latest blog post, I give a beginner-friendly guide to Multimodal RAG and share an example implementation using LLaMA 3.2 Vision and CLIP. 

Check it out here 👇 

https://lnkd.in/grY5bGDz

--
Media: Article screenshot
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Technical debt slide screenshot from ABB4 session 1

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Building a software product is easier than ever.

But there’s a hidden cost to this…

Having an LLM code your entire application helps you move fast, but will incur technical debt.

Like financial debt, technical debt involves getting some benefit now (e.g., a finished app) while delaying the cost until later (e.g., learning how it works).

The other extreme is to code your app completely from scratch and only using the Python docs.

If you do this, you’ll understand every nook and cranny of your code base, but it will take you much longer 😅 

Therefore, an important skill developers must learn today is understanding how much technical debt to take on for a specific situation.

If speed now is the top priority, then more debt can be good.

If time later is more important, then less debt is better.


👉 How do you decide how much technical debt to take on?

--
Media: Graphic
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Sharing LLM compression blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Large language models (LLMs) demonstrate impressive performance across a wide range of tasks. 

However, their immense scale can make deploying them in real-world settings a challenge 😮‍💨 

In my latest blog post, I discuss how to mitigate these challenges using model compression. 

Model compression seeks to reduce an ML model’s size without sacrificing performance. 

I review 3 types of compression techniques (i.e. Quantization, Pruning, and Knowledge Distillation) and walk through an example implementation in Python. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇

--
Media: Blog link
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Importance of full-stack data scientists and sharing blog post

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

Although it is becoming more common to split different aspects of machine learning (ML) development across multiple specialized roles (e.g., data engineers, data scientists, and ML engineers)..

.. there are still many situations which call for contributors who are well-versed in all aspects of the ML workflow. 

I call these contributors full-stack data scientists. 

👉 In my latest blog post, I introduce Full Stack Data Science and describe the 4 hats it involves. 

Check it out and let me know what you think 👇 

A big thank you to Towards Data Science for publishing this article 😁

--
Media: Blog link
LinkedIn Post Writer for Shaw Talebi, AI educator and entrepreneur

Write a LinkedIn post based on the following idea:
Employee to entrepreneur mindset shift

Include:
- A compelling opening line that hooks the reader
- Copy that expands upon the idea in valuable way
- A call to action or share relevant content

Output:

In my first 12 months of entrepreneurship, I made 1/5th of my full-time salary.

But that all changed when I made this simple mindset shift.

When I quit my job to become an entrepreneur, I asked myself:

"What work can I do to make a living?”

Looking back, I realize this was the WRONG question. Instead, I should have asked: 

“What problems can I solve?”

While the difference may seem subtle, these are fundamentally different mindsets.

The first question is what I call the “employee mindset,” which focuses on the inputs you do that eventually generate value.

The second is what I call the “entrepreneur mindset,” which focuses on the outcomes you want to create for your customer.

In my first year of entrepreneurship, I had an employee’s mindset, which resulted in me working very, very hard just to make a fraction of my full-time income (basically minimum wage) 😅 

It wasn’t until I adopted an “entrepreneur mindset” that I could match my full-time salary.

So, if you are a new or aspiring entrepreneur, ask yourself…

Am I focused more on doing a job or solving a specific pain point?

--
Media: Image
